intro: Camissonia guadalupensis subsp. clementina, commonly known as the Guadalupe camissonia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and typically grows in rocky soils along stream banks and canyons. The plant produces small, bell-shaped blue or violet flowers that bloom in the spring. It has narrow, grass-like leaves and is adapted to arid environments. This subspecies is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and limited geographic distribution.
